Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Transforming middle school mathematics into a pathway to entrepreneurship
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project is designed to address a concern that is current and increasingly significant for the U.S. economy; the decrease in entrepreneurship in our nation today. According to the Los Angeles Times (9/7/2014), "The image of the U.S. as bursting with entrepreneurial zeal, it turns out, is more myth than reality. In truth, the rate at which new companies are being formed has fallen steadily for more than three decades." There are many factors that contribute to diminished U.S. entrepreneurial activity, but there is increasing evidence that one issue that might be addressed through our education system is a new focus on "soft skills," cognitive skills that are often found under the aegis of 21st Century Skills. According to Heckman "soft skills predict success in life" they causally produce that success, and "soft skills" have an important place in an effective portfolio of public policies. This project intends to provide an environment for middle school teachers to deeply understand these entrepreneurial skills and prepare those teachers to integrate the skills into their math classrooms. Thus, another broad potential impact is the use of the model to enable teachers/schools to address 21st Century skills (precursors to entrepreneurship) within the context of the STEM disciplines.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will provide a proof-of-concept for an innovative, affordable, "next generation" personalized model for teacher professional learning that leverages today's technologies to change the way professional development is provided to teachers. It offers multiple entry points and pathways, personalizes teachers' learning, increasing the potential for applicability back to that teachers' classroom. This more affordable, actionable model professional learning environment could be expanded to include other 21st Century skills and other STEM disciplines. This project will pilot and refine this new model based on teachers' usage, satisfaction, and observed impact data. These technical objectives will be accomplished in three phases. The first is a development phase to develop multimedia learning resource library that includes high-quality, practical, useful supportive materials including innovative demonstration units of practice that demonstrate how teachers can enrich a traditional unit of study while addressing the precursor skills of entrepreneurship. These demonstration units will be embedded in a successful, affordable online learning environment for personalized teacher professional learning. The second will pilot and conduct research on this "next generation" professional learning environment. Data related to use, levels of participation and user satisfaction will be collected and analyzed. Finally, this new environment and associated resources will be refined based on the evidence collected in the pilot and research phases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview.

Market trends indicate that the economic viability of the U.S. is dependent on entrepreneurship, the engine behind innovation and the essence of the U.S. competitive advantage worldwide.  Who will be the most successful in this increasingly global marketplace? Likely it will be the nation or nations who are able to produce the greatest number and quality of successful entrepreneurs. The presence of entrepreneurship in U.S. schools is often found in one-off experiences for students where they participate in simulations focused on the experiences in developing and running a business. These experiences, coupled with business leaders visiting classrooms and offering their expertise on class projects, and student-run businesses within schools all prove valuable for students. But can we do more?

 

Metiri Group has developed a unique approach to K-12 entrepreneurship. Metiri Group has developed and piloted a new model for understanding and promoting entrepreneurial readiness in students. This model positions key non-cognitive skills and associated strategies as a blueprint for entrepreneurial readiness in students. Reviews of research have demonstrated several key non-cognitive skills that position individuals to be ready for entrepreneurship. Metiri Group is focusing on non-cognitive skills that also have high levels of classroom research and are malleable through the purposeful integration of strategies. Based on research from the business sector, Metiri Group contends that the following skills comprise entrepreneurial readiness in students: self-direction, evidence-based decision making, tolerance for ambiguity, calculated risk taking, and persistence. Each professional learning experience, designed to engage educators in the active development of these skills, is built from dynamic digital content, student tools, and classroom integration guides.

 

Metiri Group met or exceeded all of the Phase I SBIR Program Objectives.

 

The professional learning environment.

Metiri Group designed and built a personalized professional learning environment that offers teachers opportunities to learn how to get their students entrepreneur-ready. Through that online environment, Metiri  offers mini-courses where teachers can engage with content in multiple formats, downloadable tools to use with students, online knowledge tests and knowledge building games, and a certificate system that provides teachers a personalized, signed certificate to acknowledge their completion in the course. Mini-courses can be completed at the individual level, or mini-courses can be offered in a private environment with a private discussion and sharing area for teams, PLCs, schools, or districts. Individuals enrolled in mini-courses can opt-in to online meet-ups that provide access to Metiri Group leaders and focused question and answer sessions focused on classroom integration. 

 

The professional learning materials.

Metiri’s professional learning materials are grounded in current cognitive science, and related research. Each set of learning materials has been developed out to include background knowledge, scenarios of use, strategies that promote these skills, and additional digital elements that provide multiple pathways for teachers to engage, and begin implementation immediately.

 

Connect and Learn.

As part of the initial research and development, Metiri Group has created an online community focused on Developing Next Generation Entrepreneurs at edweb.net/nge. This community is a place for educators to keep in touch with our work, and participate in a number of archived webinars focused on these 5 meta-skills of entrepreneurship and access the online mini-courses.
